text: Which king oversaw the construction of the temple described in 2 Chronicles 2?
verseText: [Now Solomon purposed to build a house for the name of the LORD and a royal palace for himself.]

text: From which king did Solomon request cedar, cypress, and gold for the temple construction?
verseText: [I send you a message: 'I have work for you to do… cedar, cypress, and algum wood.']

text: Who led the Levites in consecrating the temple at its dedication in 2 Chronicles 5?
verseText: [The Levites… Heman, Asaph, and Jeduthun, with their sons and kinsmen, were clapping their hands and shouting to the LORD…]

text: What sign of divine approval appeared when Solomon finished praying at the temple dedication?
verseText: [When Solomon finished… fire came down from heaven and consumed the burnt offering and the sacrifices.]

text: Which queen visited Solomon in 2 Chronicles 9, bringing spices, gold, and precious stones?
verseText: [The queen of Sheba… when she heard of the fame of Solomon and… came to test him with hard questions.]

text: Who succeeded Solomon as king over Judah in 2 Chronicles 9?
verseText: [So Solomon reigned in Jerusalem over all Israel forty years. And Solomon slept with his fathers… and Rehoboam his son reigned in his place.]

text: Which practice did Rehoboam adopt that provoked the anger of the LORD, in 2 Chronicles 12?
verseText: [And he abandoned the law of the LORD… they did not turn from their practices.]

text: Which king of Judah famously sought the LORD in the days of Azariah the prophet, as recorded in 2 Chronicles 26?
verseText: [He sought God in the days of Zechariah… and as long as he sought the LORD, God made him prosper.]

text: Who helped Jehoshaphat by teaching in the courts of the LORD and in the cities of Judah, according to 2 Chronicles 17?
verseText: [His heart was devoted to seek the LORD… and he sent… Levites and priests to teach in Judah.]

text: Which prophet encouraged Jehoshaphat with the words, 'Do not be afraid or discouraged,' in 2 Chronicles 20?
verseText: [And he said, 'Listen, all Judah… Do not be afraid… for the battle is not yours but God’s.']

text: What condition did God set for healing the land in Solomon’s prayer, as recorded in 2 Chronicles 7:14?
options: If my people… will humble themselves
verseText: [If my people who are called by my name humble themselves… then I will heal their land.]

text: Which king found the Book of the Law in the temple and led Judah to renew the covenant, as recorded in 2 Chronicles 34?
verseText: [Shaphan… read it before the king, and the king tore his clothes.]

text: Who was the high priest that joined Joshua in leading the people during the reform under Josiah, according to 2 Chronicles 35?
verseText: [Josiah commanded the Levites… to prepare the passover… and… the priests the sons of Aaron.]

text: Which king’s reign marked the end of the divided monarchy, as noted in 2 Chronicles 36?
verseText: [Zedekiah… did evil… and all the army of the Chaldeans… captured Jerusalem.]

text: Who issued the decree allowing the exiles to return and rebuild the temple in 2 Chronicles 36?
verseText: [Thus says Cyrus king of Persia: 'The LORD… has charged me… Let him go up to Jerusalem… and rebuild the house of the LORD.']

text: What did Solomon dedicate to the LORD at the altar made of earth, as described in 2 Chronicles 1?
verseText: [Solomon built the bronze altar… and offered a thousand burnt offerings on it.]

text: Which mountain did Solomon go to offer sacrifices after the temple dedication, in 2 Chronicles 7?
verseText: [Then Solomon held the feast… before the LORD our God for seven days; and all Israel with him—a very great assembly, from Lebo-hamath to the Brook of Egypt.]

text: Who brought cedar logs from Lebanon to help with the temple construction in Solomon’s reign, according to 2 Chronicles 2?
verseText: [Send me also cedar, cypress, and algum… for the temple I am building will be great and wonderful.]

text: Which role did Jehoshaphat assign to Levites and priests during his reforms, according to 2 Chronicles 19?
verseText: [And he set judges in the land… and charged them: 'Consider what you do, for you judge not for man but for the LORD.']

text: Which prophet told Hezekiah to be strong and courageous when faced with the Assyrian threat, in 2 Chronicles 32?
verseText: [Be strong and courageous… Do not fear or be dismayed for the king of Assyria…]

text: Which of Josiah’s reforms involved tearing down houses of male cult prostitutes, according to 2 Chronicles 34?
verseText: [For he did what was right in the eyes of the LORD… he tore down the altars of the foreign gods.]

text: Which instrument does 2 Chronicles 5:12 mention among those used in the temple music?
verseText: [With their trumpets and cymbals and other musical instruments…]

text: What did Solomon ask for when God appeared to him at Gibeon, as recorded in 2 Chronicles 1?
verseText: [Give your servant… an understanding mind to govern your people and to discern between good and evil.]

text: Which group did Solomon appoint to oversee the work on the temple and the palace, according to 2 Chronicles 8?
verseText: [Solomon had all that he desired… the burnt offerings and the sin offerings.]

text: What was the primary material used for the two cherubim in the inner sanctuary, as described in 2 Chronicles 3?
verseText: [He made… two cherubim of olive wood, each ten cubits high.]

text: What phrase concludes Solomon’s dedication prayer signifying God’s presence would dwell in the temple, in 2 Chronicles 6?
verseText: [Then hear in heaven your dwelling place and forgive… so that all the peoples of the earth may know your name and fear you.]

text: How does Solomon’s choice to offer a thousand burnt offerings at Gibeon (2 Chronicles 1:3–6) illustrate his priorities as king?
options: He valued relational worship over conquest
He wanted political recognition from Egypt
He aimed to expand trade routes
verseText: [He offered sacrifices and burned incense… he went up to Gibeon to sacrifice… a thousand burnt offerings.]

text: In 2 Chronicles 7:14, why does the condition 'if my people humble themselves' connect national repentance with environmental restoration?
options: It ties covenant fidelity to land health
verseText: [If my people… humble themselves… then I will heal their land.]

text: What does the Chronicler achieve by framing Solomon’s reign with both wisdom narratives and temple construction accounts?
options: He integrates theological insight with cultic centralization
verseText: [Narratives of Solomon’s wisdom and the building of the temple…]

text: How does Jehoshaphat’s alliance with Ahab’s daughter (2 Chronicles 18) reflect both political savvy and theological risk?
options: It secured military support but compromised faith purity
It expanded trade but hindered worship
It promoted prophetic activity but weakened the throne
It improved agriculture but caused famine
verseText: [He allied himself by marriage with Ahab… they concluded a covenant.]

text: Why does the Chronicler include Jehoshaphat’s reform of appointing judges (2 Chronicles 19:5–7)?
options: To emphasize justice as foundational to godly rule
verseText: [He said to the judges… 'Consider what you do, for you judge not for man but for the LORD.']

text: In 2 Chronicles 20, how does the narrative structure of Judah’s crisis and divine deliverance model communal faith under pressure?
options: It moves from prayer to prophetic word to victory song
It focuses solely on royal decree
It centers on military strategy only
verseText: [Jehoshaphat… stood before the assembly… then the Spirit came… the enemy destroyed themselves…]

text: How does Uzziah’s leprosy incident in 2 Chronicles 26 illustrate the limits of royal authority before divine holiness?
options: It shows that access to the sanctuary belongs to priests, not kings
It validates royal supremacy over cultic law
verseText: [King Uzziah entered the temple… but he was leprous until the day of his death.]

text: What theological theme does Hezekiah’s purification of the temple in 2 Chronicles 29 emphasize?
options: Restoration of proper worship after apostasy
verseText: [Hezekiah… opened the doors of the house of the LORD… cleaned them… and restored the worship.]

text: How does the Chronicler’s portrayal of Manasseh’s repentance in 2 Chronicles 33:12–13 serve as a critique of unrepentant idolatry?
options: It contrasts earlier unfaithfulness with later humility
verseText: [Manasseh humbled himself… and the LORD brought him back to Jerusalem.]

text: Why does the Chronicler emphasize the number of Levites involved in temple reforms under Jehoiada (2 Chronicles 23)?
options: To show broad clerical support for covenant renewal
verseText: [Jehoiada gathered the captains of hundreds and… the Levites and heads of fathers’ houses of Israel to restore the house of the LORD.]

text: In what way does the Chronicler use the motif of fire descending in both Solomon’s dedication (2 Chronicles 7:1) and Jehoiada’s reforms (2 Chronicles 23:8)?
options: To signal divine endorsement of covenant actions
verseText: [Fire came down from heaven… the Levites… burned sacrifices…]

text: How does the alliance between Hezekiah and the prophet Isaiah in 2 Chronicles 32 highlight prophetic‑royal collaboration?
options: By combining faith and strategy against Assyria
By focusing only on temple liturgy
verseText: [This same Hezekiah… trusted in the LORD… therefore the LORD saved them.]

text: What does the renewal of the Passover under Hezekiah in 2 Chronicles 30 convey about national identity restoration?
options: It reintegrates the people into covenant memory
verseText: [Hezekiah sent word… that the children of Israel should celebrate the Passover…]

text: Why is the death of King Uzziah at the end of 2 Chronicles 26 narrated alongside his leprosy, and what does it signify?
options: It underscores divine judgment concluding a troubled reign
It lauds his military achievements only
verseText: [So Uzziah rested with his fathers… he was a leper to the day of his death.]

text: How does Jehoash’s repair of the temple in 2 Chronicles 24 function as a statement of collaborative leadership?
options: It mobilizes both priests and people to contribute resources
It centralizes power in the king alone
verseText: [Joash… collected money… repaired the temple with all the contributions.]

text: What does the Chronicler’s inclusion of Jehoiada’s oath renewal for the king and the people in 2 Chronicles 23:16 reveal about covenant theology?
options: It binds king and people equally under divine law
It grants immunity to the monarchy
verseText: [Then Jehoiada made a covenant between the LORD and the king and the people…]

text: How does the Chronicler frame the violent death of Joash in 2 Chronicles 24:25 as a cautionary motif?
options: It serves as a warning against forsaking God
verseText: [After the death of Jehoiada… Aristrymagus and Jozacar struck down Joash in the house of Millo.]

text: Why does the Chronicler mention the sepulcher of Zechariah in 2 Chronicles 24:20–21, and what is its significance?
options: To identify the location of righteous martyrdom
verseText: [For he was seeking to the LORD… because they did not seek to the LORD… they buried him in the city of David.]

text: In 2 Chronicles 28, how does Ahaz’s adoption of Syrian and Ephraimite religious practices illustrate the perils of syncretism?
options: It leads to national defeat and moral decline
verseText: [He burned his sons as an offering… practiced sorcery… angered the LORD.]

text: How does the Chronicler’s treatment of foreign soldiers in 2 Chronicles 17:11–12 compare to their role under David in 1 Chronicles 12?
options: They serve as auxiliaries but remain outside Israel’s covenant community
verseText: [Of Zebulun who… were experts in war… of Naphtali… who… served with bows.]

text: Why does the Chronicler record Hezekiah’s inflation of tribute to Assyria in 2 Chronicles 32:9, and what lesson does it convey?
options: Overreliance on political appeasement undermines trust in God
verseText: [He removed the hand of the LORD from him… and pyramids of silver and gold.]

text: What does Josiah’s public reading of the Book of the Law in 2 Chronicles 34:30 illustrate about the power of scripture?
options: It mobilizes national repentance and reform
verseText: [Then the king stood in his place and made a covenant before the LORD to walk after the LORD…]

text: In what way does the restoration of Passover under Hezekiah (2 Chronicles 30) differ from the original institution, and why is this significant?
options: It invites all Israel and Judah, showing inclusive covenant renewal
verseText: [Hezekiah sent to all Israel… that they should come to the house of the LORD to keep the Passover.]

text: How does the Chronicler use contrasting accounts of kings ‘doing right’ versus ‘doing evil’ in 2 Chronicles 25–36 to advance his theological agenda?
options: By linking covenant faithfulness with national stability
By focusing only on military campaigns
verseText: [Repeated refrains of ‘did right in the eyes of the LORD’ or ‘did evil’.]

text: Why does the Chronicler detail the overthrow of Athaliah in 2 Chronicles 23:12–21, and how does it underscore the theme of rightful worship?
options: To show restoration of Davidic line and temple order after apostasy
To mark a new tax system
verseText: [And they killed Athaliah with the sword… and made the covenant before the LORD…]

text: How does the Chronicler’s commentary on the length of each king’s reign (2 Chronicles 36:9–23) function as a moral evaluation?
options: Long reigns are paired with repentance; short ones with unfaithfulness
verseText: [Jehoiachin… served the king of Babylon…] / [Cyrus’s decree…]

text: What role does the motif of ‘seeking the LORD’ play in the reforms of Asa, Jehoshaphat, Hezekiah, and Josiah?
options: It marks successful reforms with charismatic leadership
It appears only in Asa’s reign
It correlates with military victories only
verseText: [They sought the LORD with all their heart…]

text: Why does the Chronicler record the temple gifts and treasuries in 2 Chronicles 31:11–12 after Hezekiah’s Passover?
options: To demonstrate generous support for ongoing worship
verseText: [Hezekiah… gave to the priests and Levites… abundantly for each day’s need.]

text: How does the Chronicler portray the fall of Jerusalem under Zedekiah (2 Chronicles 36:17–20) as the culmination of covenant unfaithfulness?
options: He attributes exile directly to repeated idolatry and ignoring prophets
verseText: [They burned the house of God… and carried the people captive.]

text: In 2 Chronicles 30:18–20, what does God’s response to Hezekiah’s prayer during the Passover reveal about divine compassion?
options: God gave them deliverance and forgiveness
verseText: [The LORD… healed the people… and turned the heart of the king of Assyria.]

text: How does the Chronicler’s use of census figures for soldiers in 2 Chronicles 17:14 and 27:6 serve his historiographical purposes?
options: They underscore divine blessing in numbers tied to faithfulness
They inflate Judah’s might for propaganda
verseText: [Zebulun… 50,000… Naphtali 1,000,000 men of valor.]

text: What does the Chronicler achieve by ending 2 Chronicles with the decree of Cyrus rather than with return narrative details?
options: He links restoration directly to divine promise fulfillment
He shifts focus to Persia’s politics
verseText: [Cyrus’s decree letting the exiles return to rebuild the temple.]

text: Analyze the chiastic structure in Solomon’s dedication prayer (2 Chronicles 6:14–42) and explain its theological significance.
options: Central plea for God’s presence framed by covenant recall
Alternating lists of tribes and offerings
Parallel accounts of David and Solomon
verseText: [When Solomon finished praying… then hear in heaven… forgive…]

text: What is the rhetorical effect of interspersing Solomon’s wisdom anecdotes (2 Chronicles 1–9) with temple construction details?
options: It balances intellectual insight with cultic centrality
It distracts from the main narrative
verseText: [Wisdom stories juxtaposed with detailed plans and execution of temple building.]

text: Discuss how the motif of divine fire both inaugurates the temple (2 Chronicles 7:1) and legitimizes Jehoiada’s coup (2 Chronicles 23:8).
options: In both instances fire signals divine endorsement of covenant acts
Fire appears only in Solomon’s reign
verseText: [Fire from heaven consumes offerings…]

text: Examine the theological implications of Uzziah’s pride and consequent leprosy (2 Chronicles 26:16–21) for understanding sacred space boundaries.
options: Kings may not overstep cultic roles reserved for priests
Leprosy is unrelated to cultic law
Priests must obey kings in all things
Royal palace is a holy place
verseText: [Uzziah entered the sanctuary to burn incense; the LORD struck him with leprosy.]

text: How does Hezekiah’s celebration of Passover in 2 Chronicles 30 function as a narrative counterpoint to Ahaz’s idolatrous practices in 2 Chronicles 28?
options: It contrasts covenant restoration with prior apostasy
verseText: [Ahaz’s sacrifices…] / [Hezekiah’s national Passover.]

text: What editorial purpose does the Chronicler serve by detailing the roles of gatekeepers, treasurers, and musicians (2 Chronicles 8–31)?
options: To portray an ideal, ordered cultic system under God’s kingship
verseText: [Overseers of the work… officers of the house of God… Levites in charge of the treasuries.]

text: In 2 Chronicles 32:24–26, Hezekiah’s pride after deliverance invites Isaiah’s rebuke. Analyze this sequence in light of covenant theology.
options: It illustrates that divine deliverance does not exempt kings from covenant faithfulness
verseText: [Yet Hezekiah did not respond according to the benefit done to him…]

text: Discuss the significance of Josiah discovering the Book of the Law (2 Chronicles 34:14–19) in shaping subsequent reforms.
options: It provides a scriptural mandate for wide‑ranging covenant renewal
It has no effect on national policy
verseText: [Hilkiah found the book…] / [Josiah tore his clothes and sought the LORD.]

text: How does the Chronicler’s portrayal of Manasseh’s later penitence (2 Chronicles 33:12–17) serve as a theological corrective to his earlier reign?
options: It shows the possibility of return even after deep apostasy
verseText: [Manasseh humbled himself greatly… and the LORD restored him.]

text: Analyze the function of covenant renewal ceremonies in the reigns of Asa (2 Chronicles 15), Jehoshaphat (2 Chronicles 20), and Josiah (2 Chronicles 34).
options: They punctuate eras where leadership aligns national identity with divine law
verseText: [Asa’s covenant… Jehoshaphat’s assembly… Josiah’s reforms.]

text: What narrative strategy does the Chronicler employ by ending with Cyrus’s decree rather than a triumphant return, and how does this shape the book’s theological horizon?
options: He emphasizes God’s sovereignty in exile restoration over human achievement
He forecasts the end of days
verseText: [Cyrus’s decree that the LORD… commanded me to build him a house at Jerusalem…]

text: Examine the Chronicler’s portrayal of the role of prophets in 2 Chronicles. How do figures like Isaiah, Zechariah, and Jahaziel function within the narrative?
options: They serve as God’s mouthpiece, guiding kings back to covenantal faith
verseText: [Jahaziel… Isaiah’s oracles… Hilkiah’s discovery.]

text: How does the Chronicler use the motif of ‘seeking the LORD’ (Heb. darash) across multiple reigns to underscore his theological message?
options: He links national flourishing directly to covenantal pursuit of God
He associates it with military prowess
verseText: [They sought the LORD with all their heart…]

text: Discuss the significance of the Chronicler’s focus on temple personnel (2 Chronicles 8; 23; 31) for understanding post‑exilic community restoration ideals.
options: He models an ideal roster of cultic roles for a renewed society
He omits all mention of temple staff
verseText: [Officers over the work… Levites appointed to oversee contributions.]

text: Analyze the portrayal of divine reward and punishment in 2 Chronicles 26–28 through the reigns of Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah.
options: Righteous reigns yield prosperity; unfaithful reigns yield calamity
Punishment is unrelated to covenant fidelity
verseText: [Uzziah’s success then leprosy… Ahaz’s idolatry… Hezekiah’s restoration.]

text: What is the significance of the Chronicler’s inclusion of detailed financial contributions in 2 Chronicles 31:11–12 and 2 Chronicles 34:9–13?
options: They demonstrate that proper worship requires communal sacrifice
verseText: [Hezekiah gave abundantly… Hilkiah’s treasures.]

text: Evaluate the Chronicler’s historiographical method in portraying the Davidic line from Solomon through Zedekiah. What patterns emerge?
options: A pattern of conditional faithfulness linked to covenant blessings
A purely chronological record without evaluation
A laudatory account of all kings
A focus on military exploits alone
verseText: [Repeated refrains of ‘did right’ or ‘did evil.’]

text: How does the Chronicler portray the relationship between royal authority and priestly/Levitical authority across 2 Chronicles?
options: Royal initiatives succeed when aligned with priestly/Levitical support
verseText: [Jehoshaphat’s judges… Jehoiada and the priesthood… Hezekiah’s Levites.]

text: Discuss the theological import of Cyrus’s decree (2 Chronicles 36:22–23) as the book’s conclusion rather than a return narrative.
options: It underscores that restoration comes by divine initiative before human action
verseText: [Cyrus… commanded to build him a house at Jerusalem in Judah.]

text: How does the Chronicler’s thematic focus on ‘seeking the LORD’ inform our understanding of leadership in 2 Chronicles?
options: Leaders who seek God foster national covenantal health
Leadership is assessed solely by military success
verseText: [They sought the LORD wholeheartedly…]

text: Analyze the role of prophetic critique in shaping Judah’s history as recorded in 2 Chronicles. How do prophets function in kings’ reforms and failures?
options: Prophets serve as divine messengers who call kings back to covenant fidelity
Prophets are absent in reform narratives
verseText: [Jahaziel… Isaiah… Hilkiah’s discovery…]

text: What does the recurrent motif of temple purification (2 Chronicles 29; 34) reveal about the Chronicler’s view of national identity?
options: That true identity is restored through right worship practices
That identity lies in military prowess
That identity depends on palace splendor
verseText: [Hezekiah’s cleansing… Josiah’s reforms.]
